ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to meet short-term obligations.

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,970,444 / $978,114 [1]. The ratio of 2.01 indicates a healthy liquidity position, suggesting the company has $2.01 in assets for every $1 of liability. This aligns with general manufacturing/distribution standards.

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as ($1,970,444 - $1,344,575) / $978,114 [1]. A ratio below 1.0 indicates heavy reliance on selling inventory to meet short-term obligations, which is typical for heavy equipment dealerships holding significant stock [2].

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $155,134 / $978,114 [2][3]. The low cash ratio suggests the company minimizes idle cash, reinvesting in inventory (which makes up the bulk of current assets).

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,970,444 - $978,114 [4]. Positive working capital of nearly $1M confirms the entity is solvent in the short term, despite the low Quick Ratio.

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and assets.

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as ($1,032,214 / $4,541,335) * 100 [5]. The margin is suppressed by high Cost of Goods Sold ($3.5M), likely due to the mix of new equipment sales which typically have lower margins than rentals/service.

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as ($842,854 / $4,541,335) * 100 [5]. Indicates efficient management of operating expenses relative to the industry standard.

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as ($423,154 / $4,541,335) * 100 [5]. The 'After Tax' margin is robust, although tax provisions ($366k) significantly reduced the 'Before Tax' margin of 17.39% [5].

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated based on Net Profit Before Tax in source [6]. Exceptionally high because Fixed Assets are presented as net-zero (fully depreciated) in this specific file version [2], artificially shrinking the asset base.

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated based on Net Profit Before Tax [6]. The extremely high ROE is driven by a small equity base ($532k) relative to the debt and earnings, indicating aggressive leverage.

ratios.name: EBITDA Margin
ratios.interpretation: Calculated using EBITDA $789,577 [4]. This matches the Pre-Tax Profit margin, implying minimal depreciation add-backs in this specific calculation set.

ratioCategories.description: Measures the extent to which the company uses debt to finance operations.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,438,326 / $532,118 [1]. Indicates the company is highly leveraged, relying nearly 3 times as much on creditor financing (Floorplan, Intercompany) than shareholder equity.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,438,326 / $1,970,444. 73% of the company's assets are financed by debt, verifying the high leverage position shown in the D/E ratio.

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $789,577 / $66,186 [7]. Despite high debt, the strong operating profit allows the company to cover interest payments almost 12 times over, indicating low default risk on interest.

ratios.name: Equity Multiplier
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,970,444 / $532,118. Shows that for every dollar of equity, the company controls $3.70 in assets, amplifying both ROE and financial risk.

ratioCategories.description: Analyzes how effectively the company uses its assets and liabilities.

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $4,541,335 / $1,970,444 [6]. High turnover suggests efficient use of the asset base to generate sales, though arguably inflated by the depreciated fixed asset value.

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $3,509,121 / $1,344,575 [8]. Indicates inventory is held for approx. 140 days. This is slower than ideal, tying up cash in equipment and parts.

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as 37.42 days [8]. The company collects receivables faster than the standard net-30/45 terms, indicating strong credit control.

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding (DPO)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as 49.30 days [9]. The company takes longer to pay vendors than it takes to collect from customers (37 days), which is beneficial for cash flow management (Cash Conversion Cycle).

ratios.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as 9.78 [8]. Confirms the efficiency of the collection department, turning over the AR balance nearly 10 times a year.

ratioCategories.description: Assesses the company's liquidity and solvency using cash flow data.

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Data Unavailable in Source: The specific 'Statement of Cash Flows' in the source file provided (Rev156-3/Rev156-1) is truncated at the 'Adjustments' line [10], preventing an accurate calculation of OCF.

ratios.name: Free Cash Flow
ratios.interpretation: Data Unavailable in Source: Due to the truncated Cash Flow Statement in source [10], CapEx and OCF cannot be definitively extracted for this specific file revision.

ratios.name: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Data Unavailable in Source: Cannot calculate without confirmed OCF figure from the Rev156-3 data set.

overallAnalysis: Based on the file 'NLTS-PR FS 12 31 2024 Rev156-3' (proxied via matching data in sources [2]-[4]), NLTS-PR demonstrates high operational efficiency and strong profit margins but operates with significant leverage. The company's Return on Equity (148%) is exceptionally high, driven by a lean equity base and high asset turnover (2.30x). Liquidity is adequate (Current Ratio 2.01), but the low Quick Ratio (0.63) and Cash Ratio (0.16) highlight a dependence on inventory turnover to meet obligations. A material discrepancy exists between the 'Rev156' draft data ($423k Net Income) and other 'Audited' versions ($182k Net Income) found in the source library, suggesting the 'Rev156' file may be a pre-tax-adjustment or internal draft version.
